site.json.title: Simple Site - The site.json file
site.json.content:
The site.json file is used to control a few of the more structural aspects of the web pages and relates to all of the pages that will be produced. It's content falls into three main parts: the meta, logos & links, and extras sections. The easiest method of creating your own site.json file is to copy the existing one that is provided with the project code and just edit it as needed. The sections shown below are cropped from a full file and contain descriptions rather than real values, for an example of real code please see this example [site.json|https://github.com/jpadfield/simple-site/blob/master/build/site.json] file.

The Meta values

'Meta elements are tags used in HTML and XHTML documents to provide structured metadata about a Web page'[@@]. They are used to defined a selection of hidden information which can be used by search engines and web browsers. At this time this project only makes use of 5 of these meta elements, further values could be added if required but this would require making adjustments to the project code rather than just the json file.

Logos & Links

As can be seen from the figure below the values in this section are reasonably straight forward and directly relate to the images and links that will appear on every page. These values are all optional and can be left blank, particularly the extra_logos details, but it is recommend that you do add an appropriate main logo and the required licence details.

Extra JS & CSS Code

For most simple projects the last section of values can be simply left blank as they are only required if more advanced users would like to add additional functionality or styling.

pages.json.title: Simple Site - The pages.json file
pages.json.content:
As noted on the main [Json|json.html] page you will need to ensure that your page is valid json, please ensure all double quotes in your added text have a / in front, like this /", also please ensure that you text is all on one line, with no newlines.

The pages.json file is used to define the actual content for your top level or main pages. The file is made up of one or more page templates, an example of which is shown below. The meaning of these fields are relatively straightforward, as described below, for an example of real code please see this example [pages.json|https://github.com/jpadfield/simple-site/blob/master/build/pages.json] file.

Each of the values within the template can include simple text information or more complex html, however you must ensure that you follow guidelines included of the main [Json|json.html] page.

In addition to standard html coding some additional options have been added to make life easier. These do not need to be used if not needed.

  • Adding footnotes: Locate footnotes references in your text using [@@], then add all of the footnote content in a comma separated list within the footnotes field in the page template, see the example below. These will all be automatically processed so that all of the footnotes added to the content or content right are numbered correctly and clickable.
  • Adding links: Links can be added to any word or phrase simply by enclosing them in square brackets, separated with a pipe character: [Display text|https://full.url.com]

An Example page template

This page template was used to define the content of the [Example|example.html], one of the actual pages within this demonstration site.

sub-pages.json.title: Simple Site - The sub-pages.json file
sub-pages.json.content:
As noted on the main [Json|json.html] page you will need to ensure that your sub-pages.json file is valid json, please ensure all double quotes in your added text have a / in front, like this /", also please ensure that you text is all on one line, with no newlines.

The sub-pages.json file is very similar to the [pages.json|pages.json.html] file, so check there for the initial description and documentation. The difference as shown below is that the sub-page template includes an extra parent field, for an example of real code please see this example [sub-pages.json|https://github.com/jpadfield/simple-site/blob/master/build/pages.json] file.

Each of the values within the template can include simple text information or more complex html, however you must ensure that you follow guidelines included of the main [Json|json.html] page.

The parent field allows you to nest pages under other pages, starting with one of the main pages, but you can then nest sub-sub-pages under sub-pages and so on if really required.

Breadcrumb Navigation

Sub-pages are not given there own tabs, as the main pages are, they are nested in dropdown menus below their parent main page. To make it easier to navigate back up a series of nested sub pages an additional [breadcrumb navigation bar|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Breadcrumb_navigation] is automatically added to all sub-pages, as shown below.

An Example Sub-page template

This page template was used to define the content of the [Example-Subpage|example-subpage-01.html], one of the actual pages within this demonstration site.

example-subpage-01.title: More detail might be needed in some areas
example-subpage-01.content: Sub pages can be set up to provide additional content without adding to the list of tabs at the top of the page. These are nested using a simple parent child relationship.

example-subpage-02.title: Another example of the same type of information
example-subpage-02.content: Lots of really great but simple text.

example-sub-subpage-01.title: Probably not needed - more nesting
example-sub-subpage-01.content: As the relationships work on a simple parent child structure more and more pages can be nested as required.

example-sub-sub-subpage-01.title: Probably not needed - more nesting
example-sub-sub-subpage-01.content: As the relationships work on a simple parent child structure more and more pages can be nested as required.
